awd_titl_txt: GOALI: OP: Incongruent Growth of Single Crystal 3D Architecture for New Optical Functionalities in Glass
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Photonic integrated circuits (PICs), the optical analog of microelectronic circuits, are key to the next major advancement in communication, sensing, information, display, and other technologies. They offer several advantages compared to discrete systems including smaller size, lower power consumption, better performance and reliability through simplification of component coupling and packaging processes, and lower cost through batch fabrication. The methods currently employed for fabricating PICs are suitable for planar geometries, whereas achieving a high density of device elements requires fabrication of 3D systems that are particularly important for optical computing, optical communication and new forms of high density optical memory. A major hurdle toward this goal is the difficulty of fabrication and integration of transparent, multifunctional micro-optical elements, which must be crystals of low symmetry rather than glass that is inherently passive. A multinational team led by researchers at Lehigh University recently demonstrated the proof-of-principle for fabricating 3D single crystal architecture in glass (SCAG) using a femtosecond (fs) laser. The present research is extending this method further for specifically realizing the concept of "principal state transmission" recently introduced by Corning, Inc. It promises to increase the transmission bandwidth of an optical fiber by an order of magnitude, thereby facilitating the next breakthrough in optical communication. In parallel, the project is training two graduate students in application-driven research through collaboration with Corning, Inc., engaging a few undergraduate students and introducing K-12 students to the emerging field of laser fabrication of new structures and devices.
 
TECHNICAL DETAILS: Nonlinear absorption of fs laser radiation allows heating a glass deep inside, at the focal point of the otherwise transmitting beam. This feature and controlled translation of the beam have been exploited in a viable method for fabricating ferroelectric SCAG in a congruently crystallizing lanthanum borogermanate model composition. However, the glass to crystal transformation becomes increasingly complex for compositions of practical interest, where the two phases have different compositions. Therefore, this GOALI collaboration between Lehigh University and Corning, Inc. is focusing on the fundamental understanding of fs laser-induced crystal growth process in continuously evolving composition, and applying this knowledge to fabricate SCAG of shape and size suitable for prototypic devices. Through continuous feedback and interactions between the teams, a correlation is being developed between the fabrication process parameters, structure of SCAG and optical performance. These results are helping to develop a predictive model that will provide guidelines for making lower optical loss SCAGs in complex compositions suitable for use in devices.

por.por_cntn:
The impact of microelectronics, optics, and photonics on communication and the quality of life is well recognized. Less widely appreciated is the transformative change that happened when 2D electronics circuitry was converted to 3D integrated circuits, which reduced the size and cost, made microelectronics a necessary commodity, and added new functionalities in devices like cell phones. A similar level of transformative change can be expected with a parallel development of 3D optics and photonics 'chip'. To help realize these advancements, a platform is needed, which would add a third dimension to the existing 2D device structure and facilitate at least transmission and manipulation of a light signal by an external electric field such as via an electro-optic crystal waveguide illustrated schematically in Figure 1.

The most significant intellectual contribution of this GOALI project is the demonstration of the proof of concept to enable 3D integrated optics in glass by fabricating the world's first optically active, ferroelectric single crystal waveguide (Fig. 2). The project further developed a comprehensive fundamental understanding of the different modes of transformation of glass into a single crystal architecture in glass (SCAG) in 3D, providing guidelines for the future development of this novel fabrication method into complex architectures as seen in Fig. 3, for example. By fusing glass of different composition, the hurdle to grow crystals in compositions that have a low propensity for nucleation was overcome (Fig. 4). In addition, a graded refractive index (GRIN) single crystal embedded in glass was realized, which would enable the guiding of light so that losses associated with the glass/crystal interface are minimized (Fig. 5). Further, ferroelectric functionality was demonstrated in lithium niobate SCAG waveguides, paving the way for active integrated optical circuit devices in a glass.

Besides contributing to enable the 3D integrated optical circuit technology, the project established the first specialized facility for femtosecond writing of single crystals in glass in the country. It trained four doctoral students in this emerging area of large social impact, who are now faculty members, entrepreneur and research scientist at a company; 10 undergraduate students at Lehigh University and Lebanon Valley College also participated in this research. The results were disseminated via six archival publications and 42 invited and contributed talks at national and international conference, while seven invited colloquia lectures were delivered to broader audiences at as many universities. For the invention of a single-crystal graded refractive index active waveguide in glass, a patent was granted. The grant further contributed to a STEM outreach program for girls at the Broughal Middle School that serves a predominantly Hispanic population.
